author: , York Dispatch
title: Rain forces York-Adams League to cancel 2024 softball tournament
text: The York-Adams League the cancellation of its softball tournament Friday afternoon after rainy weather forced a slew of postponements. The league cited "the rainy spring, continued bad weather today, and the forecast" as the reason for bagging the tournament, which was scheduled for next Wednesday and Thursday, May 15 and 16. The York-Adams baseball tournament was previously canceled on Wednesday. While some York-Adams League teams had already completed their regular seasons, others entered Friday with as many three games remaining on the schedule. Games must be played by next Thursday to count toward the District 3 power rankings. District tournaments in six classifications begin Monday, May 20. In addition to Friday, Rain is forecasted within the league's footprint on Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Both the baseball and softball tournaments have now been wiped out four times in the past seven years. The entire 2020 season was canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic, while a bevy of COVID-related postponements wiped out the league's spring championships in 2021. Rainy weather also forced the cancellation of the 2018 tournaments. South Western (20-0, 15-0 Division I) and Kennard-Dale (14-4, 13-1 Division III) have secured outright division titles and were slated to meet in the tournament semifinals on Wednesday. New Oxford and Northeastern were still battling for the D-II crown, while Biglerville and Delone Catholic were set to decide their Division IV race with a pair of head-to-head meetings started Friday. Those matchups are provisionally scheduled for Monday and Tuesday. Littlestown won the 2023 softball tournament with a walk-off win over South Western. The York-Adams League will now stage just two postseason tournaments next week, both at Dallastown High School. The boys' and girls' lacrosse semifinals were contested Thursday and the championship games are set for 5 and 7 p.m. Tuesday. The four-team boys' volleyball tournament, meanwhile, will be contested Monday and Tuesday. Boys' lacrosse: Ungerland twins lead Dallastown to York-Adams final vs. Central York Girls' lacrosse: Dallastown prevails in 3OT; York Catholic awaits in York-Adams final Boys' volleyball: Central York tops Northeastern for boys' volleyball league title Girls' track & field: Bahn, Carlson headline record-breaking day at York-Adams championships Boys' track & field: Red Lion's Strausbaugh sprints to the summit at York-Adams track championships

author: Il Resto del Carlino
title: "Ristorazione collettiva . Meritiamo più dignità"
text:
Carmen Vallotta, settore ristorazione
"Lavoro nel mondo della ristorazione collettiva da ormai diciotto anni – le parole di Carmen Vallotta, rappresentante sindacale Cgil – e non posso nascondere che le preoccupazioni ci sono, sono parecchie e soprattutto si fanno sentire. Nel nostro settore contiamo per lo più lavoratrici donne, inquadrate con part-time da 15 o 20 ore, accettati a malincuore pur di portare uno stipendio, per quanto basso, a casa per vivere. O meglio, per sopravvivere. Molte di loro sono precarie e devono sostenere una famiglia: è ora che anche questo settore abbia dignità".
Il grido di Vallotta è forte e chiaro: "La manovra del governo non fa nulla per contrastare questa precarietà contrattuale e il nostro è tra i settori maggiormente penalizzati – continua – Bisogna invertire la rotta, a partire dagli stipendi. Purtroppo già oggi le giovani donne che lavorano nella ristorazione collettiva sono in difficoltà: c’è chi fatica a diventare indipendente perché con salari così bassi non riuscirebbe nemmeno a pagare l’affitto. Che prospettive possiamo dare alle nuove generazioni?". "Gli aumenti che ci sono stati sono risultati minimi, e totalmente insufficienti. Chiediamo – continua Vallotta – stipendi adeguati all’inflazione, per stare al passo e poter vivere dignitosamente. Bisogna prendere coscienza di quanto sta accadendo e non rassegnarsi, far sentire la propria voce per dire ’no’. I nostri diritti, sanciti dalla Costituzione, devono essere applicati su tutte le tematiche: iscrizione, lavoro, sanità. Perché con i tagli che stanno attuando, oggi siamo poveri pur lavorando e non possiamo neanche permetterci di ammalarci".
Pagina a cura
di Giorgia De Cupertinis

author: James Herrera
title: Paul’s Slide on Highway 1 near Big Sur opens Sunday
text:
BIG SUR – Highway 1 at Paul’s Slide is set to reopen Sunday, according to Caltrans, which credits favorable site conditions and recent construction progress with the earlier than expected completion. It opens access to the community of Lucia, Camaldoli Hermitage, and residents living within the newly reopened 4.3 miles of highway.
Since Jan. 14, 2023, direct access on Highway 1 through Paul’s Slide has not been possible due to a major slide that displaced an estimated 500,000 cubic yards of material that engulfed the roadway. Earlier this month, Caltrans said the slide location would be ready to open early to mid-July.
“The challenge at Paul’s Slide has always been to repair Highway 1 while movement continues within the slide location,” said Caltrans Director Tony Tavares in a press release. “The completion of repairs and the reopening of a 4.3-mile section of this scenic byway will begin to restore some normalcy for business owners and residents in the area.”
On June 7, repair work at the Dolan Point Side – post mile 29.5 – was completed, four months after it occurred, but it will not change the turnaround point for southbound traffic.
“With the completion of repairs at the Dolan Point Slide, the turnaround point for southbound Highway 1 traffic will remain in place at Lime Creek – post mile 32.1 – until repairs are complete at Regent’s Slide,” said Kevin Drabinski, Caltrans District 5 spokesman. “The northern turnaround point at Lime Creek is well suited as a turnaround location as it offers a good line of sight on approach and provides ample space for large vehicles to turn around.”
Repairs at Dolan Point involved a top-down removal of slide material and reduction of rocks by blasting crews, after which double twist cable mesh was installed along the face of the slope.
“Crews connected the seams of dozens of 150-foot lengths of mesh which were lifted into place by helicopter. This mesh will add an additional layer of protection to the highway below the slope,” explained Drabinski.
Now that Paul’s Slide – post mile 22 – is opening, traffic coming from the south will be able to come as far north as repair work on the Regent’s Slide – post mile 27.8 – will comfortably allow. The southern turnaround point on Highway 1 will move from Limekiln State Park – post mile 21 – northward to just south of Vicente Creek Bridge – post mile 25.3 – where travelers will have a clear line of sight on approach and ample space for large vehicles to maneuver and turn around.
After the reopening at Paul’s Slide, crews will be on site over the next several weeks to remove additional slide material, complete drainage installation and implement erosion control measures. Travelers will encounter intermittent traffic control with only minimal delays during this work.
The contractor for repairs at Paul’s Slide is Papich Construction of Arroyo Grande, according to Caltrans. The total cost of this project is approximately $60 million.
Repair work at the last remaining closure point on Highway 1 will continue at Regent’s Slide where the northern turnaround point remains at Lime Creek just south of the Esalen Institute. Caltrans estimates repairs at Regent’s Slide will be complete by late fall, at which time Highway 1 will once again be open to direct travel along the entire route of the Big Sur coast between Carmel and Cambria.
Tavares thanked the local community for its patience and support during the time it took to repair Paul’s Slide. He said the state agency also wants to express appreciation for the persistence, ingenuity, and resolve demonstrated by Caltrans personnel and contracted crews throughout this process.
Road information and updates can also be found on Caltrans District 5 Social Media platforms: Twitter at: @CaltransD5, Facebook at: Caltrans Central Coast (District 5) and Instagram at: Caltrans_D5.

author: flavia.
title: Guerra en Ucrania: presencia confirmada de soldados norcoreanos, Putin no lo niega, armas procedentes de Se\u00fal\u2026 actualizaci\u00f3n de la situaci\u00f3n
text: Cada día, Midi Libre hace balance de la situación en Ucrania. Este jueves 24 de octubre de 2024 descubre las últimas novedades en torno a este conflicto. Corea del Sur estudiará la posibilidad de suministrar armas a Ucrania Corea del Sur estudiará “con más flexibilidad” Anteriormente se había descartado la posibilidad de suministrar armas a Ucrania tras los informes sobre el despliegue de tropas norcoreanas en Rusia, anunció el jueves el presidente Yoon Suk Yeol. “Aunque hemos seguido el principio de no proporcionar directamente armas letales, podemos revisar este tema de manera más flexible dependiendo de las acciones de las fuerzas norcoreanas”.Dijo Yoon en una conferencia de prensa con el presidente polaco, Andrzej Duda, en Seúl. Soldados norcoreanos en combate: Putin no lo niega, Kiev confirma El presidente ruso, Vladimir Putin, preguntado sobre el supuesto despliegue de soldados norcoreanos en Rusia, no desmintió esta información de la inteligencia occidental, evitando responder directamente. “Nunca hemos dudado de que los norcoreanos se toman en serio nuestros acuerdos (cooperación, nota del editor)”afirmó en una conferencia de prensa durante la cumbre de los BRICS en Kazán, añadiendo que “Es nuestro negocio”. Ucrania dijo el jueves que se habían desplegado soldados norcoreanos en la región rusa de Kursk, donde las tropas ucranianas controlan cientos de kilómetros cuadrados, ya que Occidente teme que su participación en los combates pueda conducir a una escalada importante de la guerra. “Las primeras unidades del ejército norcoreano, que fueron entrenadas en polígonos del este de Rusia, ya han llegado a la zona de combate”afirmó en un comunicado el servicio de inteligencia militar de Ucrania (GUR). “El 23 de octubre de 2024 se registró su aparición en la región (rusa) de Kursk”agregaron. Putin advierte que la paz con Kiev debe basarse “en las realidades” del campo de batalla El presidente ruso, Vladimir Putin, dijo el jueves que la paz con Kyiv debe basarse “sobre las realidades” del campo de batalla en Ucrania, donde el ejército del Kremlin todavía controla casi el 20% del territorio. “Estamos dispuestos a considerar cualquier negociación de paz basada en las realidades sobre el terreno. No estamos dispuestos a hacer nada más”.insistió durante una rueda de prensa. El presidente ruso Vladimir Putin también juzgó “ilusorio” de querer derrotar a Rusia en el campo de batalla de Ucrania, donde las tropas rusas están ganando terreno en el Este, tras 32 meses de conflicto de alta intensidad. “No ocultan su objetivo de infligir una derrota estratégica a nuestro país”lanzó Putin, en referencia a los países occidentales que apoyan militarmente a Ucrania. “Son cálculos ilusorios que sólo pueden hacer quienes no conocen la historia de Rusia y no tienen en cuenta su unidad forjada durante siglos”afirmó en un discurso en la cumbre de los Brics celebrada en Kazán. El opositor ruso Navalnaïa deplora que Guterres se reuniera con “el asesino” Putin La opositora rusa en el exilio, Yulia Navalnaïa, deploró el hecho de que el secretario general de la OTAN, Antonio Guterres, estrechara la mano del presidente ruso Vladimir Putin el jueves, una “asesino”durante la cumbre de los Brics en Kazán. “Es el tercer año de guerra y el secretario general de la ONU le da la mano a un asesino”abordó en un mensaje publicado en X. MM. Putin y Guterres aún deben reunirse cara a cara por la noche, según el programa oficial del Kremlin.
